Comment: It depends what you mean by "schools."  "Schools" as in K-12, kind of?  CRT is an academic concept and more of a framework to examine historical events and perspectives. It's not something that you can teach per say and it's definitely not something you can use to teach math or science or subjects like that.  It's like saying "They're using the scientific method to teach English!" It doesn't really work like that.  At the base, CRT literally just says that laws and social developments are shaped in part by social conceptions of race and ethnicity - the racial/ethnic history of a place impacts how the laws and society develops.  That's it. That's literally it.  To say in a class "Laws have been made with the intent to focus on specific racial communities" is something that no one who had a rational view of history would argue with. "Critical race theory" a five dollar word to talk about that.   So you *could* say that CRT is being taught in schools but all that is is putting a name to the acknowledgement that race plays a part in the social and legal developments of a nation.

Comment: >When republicans talk about CRT, they mostly mean 'anything race-related    that I don't like', and they just call it all CRT.  They also    misrepresent what's actually being taught quite a bit in those cases.  This can largely be traced back to one conservative activist: Christopher Rufo.  Rufo described his strategy to oppose critical race theory as intentionally using the term to conflate various race-related ideas in order to create a negative association.  Rufo said that "\[w\]e will eventually turn \[critical race theory\] toxic,  as we put all of the 'various cultural insanities' under that brand category. The goal is to have the public read something 'crazy' in the newspaper and immediately think 'critical race theory'."  The idea was to basically conflate any liberal social/cultural talking point with "CRT."
